</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">62 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Net income </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">AEGON
reported a net loss in the Netherlands for H1 2009 of EUR 37 million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Fair value items include the under/overperformance on assets held at fair value
through profit and loss, backing liabilities of a specific portfolio of group pension contracts held in the general account. In H1 2009 these assets underperformed long-term expected returns by EUR 54 million. The assets backing this portfolio of
liabilities were accounted for as fair value through profit or loss and have been replaced with assets accounted for as available for sale. As a result this item will not recur as fair value item going forward. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Earnings in H1 2009 include a EUR 189&nbsp;million charge from the net impact of movements in the fair value of guarantees and related hedges. The significant benefits
of higher equity markets and lower equity market volatility were more than offset by losses from the company&#146;s program for managing guarantee-related interest exposures. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Impairments of EUR 106&nbsp;million were primarily related to equity investments and corporate credit investments. Investment gains and losses amounted to EUR 68&nbsp;million and include gains on bonds and shares sold
during H1 2009, partly offset by losses resulting from a revaluation of direct residential real estate investments. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Underlying earnings before tax </B>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">AEGON reported underlying earnings of EUR 201&nbsp;million in the Netherlands in H1 2009, down 12%, a result of lower technical results in the life and
pension business and adverse claims experience in general insurance. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Underlying earnings before tax from Life&nbsp;&amp; Protection amounted to EUR
130&nbsp;million, up from H1 2008 primarily because of a EUR 20&nbsp;million one-time release of provisions and higher investment income in the Life business, partly offset by lower technical results. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Savings business reported an underlying loss before tax of EUR 19&nbsp;million, due to continued pressure on margins and volumes from fierce competition in the
savings market. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Underlying earnings before tax from Pensions&nbsp;&amp; Asset Management amounted to EUR 83&nbsp;million, 25% down from earnings in H1
2008, which had included a one-time release of accruals. Lower asset balances resulted in lower fee income. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Underlying earnings before tax from
Distribution amounted to EUR 12&nbsp;million, down from H1 2008 because of a slowdown in the real estate market. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">General insurance underlying earnings
before tax were down significantly to a loss of EUR 5&nbsp;million, lower than H1 2008 due to higher claims experience. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Commissions and expenses </B>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Commissions and expenses were down 5%, while operating expenses decreased by 4%, both compared to H1 2008. Operating expenses were down as a result of cost
initiatives taken during the first six months, e.g. a reduction in staff and in project-related expenses. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Sales and deposits </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Pension sales decreased significantly during H1 2009 and proved volatile after the standstill in the Dutch group pension market during H2 2008. Sales of single premium
individual life products were down compared to H1 2008, following increased pricing competition in the immediate annuity market, as well as lower demand for regular premium products. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Gross deposits were level with H1 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">63 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>By secondary segment</B></FONT></P></TD>

</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Included in other non-operating income/(charges) are charges made to policyholders with respect to income tax. There is an equal and opposite tax charge which is
reported in the line Income tax attributable to policyholder return. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Includes production on investment contracts without a discretionary participation feature of which the proceeds are not recognized as revenues but are directly
added to our investment contract liabilities. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="3" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Six&nbsp;months&nbsp;ended&nbsp;June&nbsp;30</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ROWSPAN="2" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>June&nbsp;30,</B></FONT><br><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>2009</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ROWSPAN="2" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Dec. 31,</B></FONT><br><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>2008</B></FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" NOWRAP> <P STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000;width:36pt"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Per 1 EUR</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>2008</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>2008</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">GBP</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">0.8920</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">0.7763</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">0.8521</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">0.9525</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Net income </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Net income amounted to GBP 23&nbsp;million, a decline compared to H1 2008 due to lower underlying earnings and higher impairments. Net investment gains totaled GBP 34&nbsp;million, including a GBP 15&nbsp;million accounting gain on a
derivative instrument for which hedge accounting could no longer be applied. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Underlying earnings before tax </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Underlying earnings before tax declined to GBP 24&nbsp;million compared to H1 2008, due primarily to the impact of lower equity and corporate bond markets on fund related
charges in AEGON&#146;s unit-linked pension business in the United Kingdom. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Underlying earnings before tax from Life&nbsp;&amp; Protection totaled GBP
18&nbsp;million in H1 2009, in line with last year. Growth in the annuity and protection business was offset by one-time charges related to the withdrawal from the group employee benefit business and lower investment income. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Underlying earnings before tax from Pensions&nbsp;&amp; Asset Management amounted to GBP 11&nbsp;million, a decline of GBP 44&nbsp;million, due to a decrease in fund
related charges as a result of lower equity and bond markets. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Distribution activities in H1 2009 experienced an underlying loss before tax of GBP
5&nbsp;million, largely because of continued difficult market conditions for mortgage and investment products. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Commissions and expenses </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Total commissions and expenses in H1 2009 were up 2% compared to H1 2008. Commissions were lower because of a change in AEGON&#146;s business mix in the United
Kingdom. Operating expenses increased by 3% to GBP 206&nbsp;million, due mainly to restructuring expenses. H1 2008 had included a provision release related to incentive payments in the asset management business. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Sales and deposits </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">New life sales amounted to GBP 488&nbsp;million
in H1 2009. Compared to H1 2008, sales were down across most products. Group pension sales in H1 2008 included one large case. Sales from investment bonds suffered from tax changes and worsening market conditions. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">65 </FONT></P>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Other countries </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>Net income </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Other countries recorded a net loss of EUR 334&nbsp;million in H1 2009 as a result of a book loss of EUR 385&nbsp;million from
the sale of the company&#146;s Taiwanese life insurance activities. Excluding this one-time loss, net income amounted to EUR 51&nbsp;million, compared to EUR 48&nbsp;million in the same period last year. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Underlying earnings before tax </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Underlying earnings before tax from
Other countries increased compared to H1 2008 to EUR 77&nbsp;million in H1 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Underlying earnings before tax from Life&nbsp;&amp; Protection were level
at EUR 26 million. In H1 2008 life earnings from CEE included a one-off reserve release in Hungary of EUR 4 million. This was offset by higher surrender charges, a reduction in expenses in CEE and further business growth at AEGON&#146;s joint
ventures in Spain in H1 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The inclusion of variable annuities in Europe and continued growth at the asset management joint venture in China led to
underlying earnings before tax of EUR 11&nbsp;million from Individual Savings and Retirement products in H1 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Pensions&nbsp;&amp; Asset Management
underlying earnings before tax increased to EUR 10&nbsp;million as a result of the introduction earlier this year of DPAC in the pension business in Hungary and Poland. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Underlying earnings before tax from General Insurance decreased to EUR 16&nbsp;million as a result of higher claim ratios. Despite this increase, however, these ratios remained well within pricing assumptions.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Commissions and expenses </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Commissions and expenses
decreased by 17% as higher operating expenses were more than offset by lower commissions and higher deferred expenses. In addition, the sale of AEGON Taiwan at the end of the first quarter contributed to the decrease in commissions and expenses.
Commissions decreased also as a result of lower sales, while expanding operations led to an increase in expenses. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Sales and deposits </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Market turmoil continued to affect sales compared to last year. New life sales totaled EUR 97&nbsp;million in H1 2009, a decrease compared to H1 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In CEE both single and recurring premium production decreased compared to H1 2008, resulting in total new life sales of EUR 33 million. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In Asia, new life sales decreased to EUR 18 million. In China, new life sales increased as a result of strong recurring premium product sales, especially in the broker
and bank channels. This was more than offset by a decline in Taiwan, mainly due to the sale of the life insurance operations at the beginning of the second quarter. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">New life sales in Spain were up 22% to EUR 46&nbsp;million, primarily as a result of increased recurring premium production at AEGON&#146;s joint ventures with savings banks compared to H1 2008. New life sales from
the partnership with CAM, which is not consolidated in AEGON&#146;s accounts, amounted to EUR 123&nbsp;million (on a 100% basis). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">67 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>vi Subsequent events </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">On July&nbsp;13, 2009, AEGON reached a final agreement with Stichting Verliespolis and Stichting Woekerpolis Claim to reduce charges for customers of its unit-linked insurance policies in the Netherlands. The agreement is part of
industry-wide efforts in the Netherlands to address concerns over charges related to unit-linked insurance products. As a result of the final agreement, there will be an additional impact on the company&#146;s embedded value of approximately EUR 70
mln after tax. The cost of improvements will be reflected in AEGON&#146;s earnings over the remainder of the lifespan of affected policies. Consequently, no significant impact on the 2009 income statement is expected as provisions are adequate.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;5, 2009, the Enterprise Chamber of the Amsterdam court of appeals in the Netherlands ruled in favor of AEGON in connection with a dispute
with harbor trade unions regarding the consolidation of equity of OPTAS, a life insurance company AEGON acquired at the beginning of 2007. The court rejected a request to order a restatement of the company&#146;s financial statements. The ruling is
open to appeal to the Dutch Supreme Court. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;13, 2009 AEGON announced that it has completed a EUR 1 billion equity issue via an accelerated
bookbuild. The issue was conducted under AEGON&#146;s USD Shelf Registration through the sale of a combination of new common shares and existing treasury shares. The issue comprised 157,822,000 new common shares and 32,654,191 treasury shares of
AEGON N.V. with a nominal value of EUR 0.12. The shares were sold at a price of EUR 5.25&nbsp;per Netherlands registered share and USD 7.50&nbsp;per New York registered share. Application has been made to list the new shares on respectively Euronext
Amsterdam, the principal market for AEGON&#146;s common shares, and the New York Stock Exchange. The issue has been settled on August&nbsp;19, 2009 and the new shares are admitted to trading on respectively Euronext Amsterdam and the New York Stock
Exchange as of that date. AEGON intends to use the proceeds of the equity issue to repay up to EUR 1 billion of the total EUR 3 billion of core capital obtained last year from its largest shareholder, Vereniging AEGON, funded by the Dutch State. The
decision to repay by December&nbsp;1, 2009, is conditional on AEGON&#146;s capital position at the time of repayment and the outlook for the economy and financial markets not deteriorating materially. The repayment further requires the formal
consent of the Dutch Central Bank (DNB). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;27, 2009 AEGON announced that the life insurance joint venture between AEGON and Sony Life has
obtained final approval from the Japanese regulatory authorities to launch business operations later this year. The 50-50 joint venture &#150; known as AEGON Sony Life Insurance Co., Ltd. (ASLIC) &#150; will initially focus on the sale of variable
annuity products which will be distributed through Sony Life&#146;s &#145;Lifeplanner&#146; sales employees, as well as banks and other financial institutions. ASLIC is expected to begin operations in early December. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;31, 2009 AEGON announced the completion of the sale of its Taiwan life insurance business to Zhongwei Company, a holding company established and funded by
a consortium led by the Chairman of Meifu Development and the President of Taiwan Glass Industry. The entering by the parties into an agreement for the sale was originally announced on April&nbsp;22, 2009. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>vii Liquidity and capital resources </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>General </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The main goals of AEGON&#146;s capital and liquidity management are to ensure strong capital adequacy, manage and allocate capital efficiently across the company in order
to maximize sustainable returns, and ensure ongoing access to money markets and capital markets on competitive terms such that the cost of capital is minimized. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Along with the mentioned goals, the funding and capital management process aims to ensure that high standards of liquidity are maintained even during periods of severely impaired financial markets. These goals support AEGON&#146;s capacity
to withstand losses from severely adverse business and market conditions and help to serve the interests of all its stakeholders. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">AEGON conducts its
funding and capital management processes at various levels within the organization, coordinated by Group Treasury, under the remit of the Group Risk and Capital Committee. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Capital adequacy </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">AEGON manages capital adequacy at the level of its country units and their operating companies. The goal
is to ensure that AEGON companies maintain their strong financial strength, now and into the future, even after sustaining losses from severely adverse business and market conditions. AEGON maintains its companies&#146; capital adequacy levels at
whichever is the higher of local regulatory requirements, the relevant local Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s requirements for very strong capitalization, and any additionally self-imposed economic requirements. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">68 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During the first half of 2009, the capital adequacy of AEGON&#146;s operating units continued to be strong. At
June&nbsp;30, 2009, the AEGON Group had excess capital over these self-imposed requirements of EUR 3.5 billion partially held by AEGON N.V., up EUR 0.6 billion from end of 2008. To strengthen its capital adequacy, AEGON has carried out capital
preservation initiatives resulting in EUR 1.6 billion capital released from AEGON&#146;s businesses during the first half of 2009, above the target of EUR 1.5 billion that had been set for the full year of 2009. While AEGON is continuing with its
effort to release capital from its businesses it has also started to redeploy the capital by investing cash in higher yielding quality assets and higher return business opportunities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The AEGON Group does not manage its capital based on the EU Insurance Group Directive (IGD). However, AEGON does report its IGD ratio. At June&nbsp;30, 2009, the Group&#146;s IGD ratio was 202%. This ratio takes into
account Solvency 1 capital requirements based on IFRS for entities within the EU, as well as local regulatory solvency measurements for non-EU entities. Specifically, required capital for the life insurance companies in the United States is
calculated as two times the upper end of the Company Action Level range (200%), as applied by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) in the United States. Since the end of 2008, the methodology to calculate The Netherlands&#146;
IGD ratio was aligned with the Solvency I calculation for Dutch companies which takes into account the positive balance of the Dutch &#145;Toereikendheidstoets&#146; (&#145;TRT&#146;) or the local regulatory liability adequacy test. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Capital base and leverage tolerances </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">AEGON applies leverage
tolerances to its capital base. The capital base reflects the capital employed across the group and consists of core capital (which consists of shareholders&#146; equity, excluding revaluation reserve, as well as convertible core capital
securities), perpetual capital securities (including currency revaluations), dated subordinated debt and senior debt. AEGON targets its capital base to comprise at least 70% core capital, and targets 25% perpetual capital securities and 5% dated
subordinated debt and senior debt. At June&nbsp;30, 2009, AEGON&#146;s capital base consisted of 75% core capital, and 21% perpetual capital securities. Senior and dated subordinated debt accounted for the remaining 4%. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Excess Capital is the capital in excess of the most stringent capital adequacy requirement adhered to by AEGON for its operating companies plus the Excess Capital held
at AEGON N.V. Additional Leverage Capacity is defined as the maximum capacity to issue additional debt under the leverage tolerance defined in the paragraph above. AEGON defines Financial Flexibility as the sum of Excess Capital and Additional
Leverage Capacity. Financial Flexibility is a self-imposed managerial limitation for assuming debt and gives an indication of the capacity of the Group to assume debt. In April 2009, AEGON used its Leverage Capacity by issuing EUR 1 billion of
Senior Unsecured Notes under its USD 6 billion Program for the Issuance of Debt Instruments. At June&nbsp;30, 2009, AEGON&#146;s Financial Flexibility was EUR 3.5 billion. Current liquidity needs are amply covered by excess cash held within the
Group. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Core capital and Group equity </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Core
capital, which consists of shareholders&#146; equity and the convertible core capital securities which were issued in 2008 (see below), was EUR 10,642&nbsp;million at June&nbsp;30, 2009, compared with EUR 9,055&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,
2008. The main drivers of the increase were a net loss of EUR 334&nbsp;million, an increase in the revaluation reserve of EUR 2,056&nbsp;million, an increase in the foreign currency translation reserve, dividend payments and coupon payments on
perpetual capital securities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Group equity consists of core capital plus other equity securities, such as the Junior Perpetual Capital Securities and the
Perpetual Cumulative Capital Securities, as well as other equity reserves. The other equity securities accounted for EUR 4,645&nbsp;million at June&nbsp;30, 2009. The Perpetual Capital Securities possess features that may result in a deferral of
coupons. Group equity was EUR 15,352&nbsp;million at June&nbsp;30, 2009 (including currency revaluations on other equity securities), compared with EUR 13,760&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In the context of the unprecedented market conditions that materialized in 2008, AEGON secured on December&nbsp;1, 2008, an additional EUR 3 billion in core capital from
Vereniging AEGON, funded by the Dutch State, as part of a broader program to support fundamentally sound and viable banks and insurance companies in the Netherlands during the financial crisis. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;13, 2009 AEGON completed a EUR 1 billion equity issue via an accelerated book build. The issue was conducted under AEGON&#146;s USD Shelf Registration
through the sale of a combination of new common shares and existing treasury shares. The issue comprised 157,822,000 new common shares and 32,654,191 treasury shares of AEGON N.V. with a nominal value of EUR 0.12. The shares were sold at a price of
EUR 5.25&nbsp;per Netherlands registered share and USD 7.50&nbsp;per New York registered share. AEGON intends to use the proceeds of the equity issue to repay up to EUR 1 billion of the total EUR 3 billion of core capital obtained last year from
Vereniging AEGON, funded by the Dutch State. The decision to repay by December&nbsp;1, 2009, is conditional on AEGON&#146;s capital position at the time of repayment and the outlook for the economy and financial markets not deteriorating materially.
The repayment further requires the formal consent of the Dutch Central Bank (DNB). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">69 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Debt funding </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">AEGON&#146;s funding strategy continues to be based on ensuring ongoing access to international capital markets, while minimizing the cost of capital. AEGON&#146;s focus on a well established fixed income investor base is supported by an
active investor relations program designed to keep investors informed on AEGON&#146;s strategy and results. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">AEGON&#146;s liquidity management strategy is
aimed at maintaining sufficient liquidity to ensure that the company can meet its payment obligations as they fall due at a reasonable cost. This is achieved by dispersing day-to-day funding requirements, maintaining a broad base of funding sources
and maintaining a well-diversified portfolio of highly liquid assets. Liquidity is managed at both Group and country unit levels. AEGON&#146;s liquidity position remained strong through the first half of 2009. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Most of AEGON&#146;s debt is issued by the parent company, AEGON N.V. In addition, a limited number of other AEGON companies, whose securities are guaranteed by AEGON
N.V., have issued debt securities. AEGON N.V. has regular access to the capital markets under its USD 6 billion Programme for the issuance of Debt Instruments. On April&nbsp;22, 2009 AEGON N.V. issued EUR 1 billion 3-year Senior Unsecured Notes
under this program. The Notes, issued at a price of 99.673, carry a coupon of 7%. Access to the US markets is facilitated by a separate US shelf registration. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">AEGON N.V.&#146;s and AEGON Funding Company LLC&#146;s (guaranteed by AEGON N.V.) combined USD 4.5 billion Euro and US Commercial Paper Programs provide access to domestic and international money markets. At June&nbsp;30, 2009, AEGON N.V.
had EUR 250&nbsp;million outstanding under its commercial paper programs. AEGON has a short-term debt rating of P2/A2/F1 by, respectively, Moody&#146;s, S&amp;P and Fitch. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">AEGON maintains back-up credit facilities to support outstanding amounts under its commercial paper programs. The principal arrangement is a USD 5 billion syndicated facility including a USD 3 billion back-up facility
maturing in 2012. This arrangement also includes a USD 2 billion multicurrency revolving letter of credit facility maturing in 2015, extendable until 2017. In addition, AEGON maintains USD 475&nbsp;million of shorter dated bilateral back-up
facilities. AEGON N.V. has not drawn any amounts under any liquidity back-up facilities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Internal sources of liquidity include distributions from
operating subsidiaries. Internal distributions may be subject to (local) regulatory requirements. Excess liquidity is invested in highly liquid, short-term assets in accordance with internal risk management policies. The duration profile of
AEGON&#146;s capital leverage is managed in line with the duration of surplus assets related to investments in its subsidiaries, subject to liquidity needs, capital and other requirements. AEGON considers its working capital, backed by the external
funding programs and facilities, to be amply sufficient for the Group&#146;s present requirements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Operational leverage is not part of the capital base.
At June&nbsp;30, 2009, operational leverage was EUR 2.9 billion (December 31, 2008: EUR 2.1 billion). Operational debt primarily relates to mortgage warehousing and the funding of US regulation XXX and Guideline AXXX redundant reserves. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Ratings </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Claims paying ability and financial strength ratings are
factors in establishing the competitive position of insurers. An isolated rating downgrade of AEGON or any of its rated insurance subsidiaries, where a certain number of the relevant peers did not also get similarly downgraded, may, among other
things, materially increase the number of policy surrenders and withdrawals by policyholders of cash values from their policies. The outcome of this may be cash payments requiring the sale of invested assets, including illiquid assets, at a price
that may result in realized investment losses. Such cash payments to policyholders would result in a decrease in total invested assets as well as a decrease in net income. Among other things, early withdrawals may also cause AEGON to accelerate
amortization of policy acquisition costs, reducing net income. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, a rating downgrade may adversely affect relationships with broker-dealers,
banks, agents, wholesalers and other distributors of AEGON&#146;s products and services. This may negatively impact new sales and adversely affect the Group&#146;s ability to compete. This would have a materially adverse effect on AEGON&#146;s
business, results of operations and financial condition. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">70 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The current Fitch, Moody&#146;s and Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s (S&amp;P) insurance financial strength ratings (IFSR)
and ratings outlook of the Group&#146;s primary life insurance companies in AEGON&#146;s major country units are shown in the following table: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B><I>Ratings </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of June&nbsp;30, 2009 </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">NR</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A3</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Moody&#146;s outlook</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Negative </FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Negative </FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Negative </FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Negative</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Fitch rating</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">AA</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">NR</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Fitch outlook</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Negative </FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Negative </FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Negative </FONT></TD>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">1</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">NR is Not Rated </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During the first half of 2009,
Moody&#146;s lowered its senior debt rating for AEGON N.V. to A3 with a negative outlook; Fitch lowered its senior debt rating to A with a negative outlook, while Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s lowered its senior debt rating to A-. The outlook for
all three credit ratings remained negative. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At the same time, Moody&#146;s, Fitch and S&amp;P also lowered the Insurance financial strength ratings of
AEGON USA by one notch, to A1, AA and AA-, respectively. These downgrades were in line with similar actions taken by credit rating agencies affecting many of our peers as well as several other companies broadly across the insurance industry. Due to
this relative context, along with the decision to run off the IMD spread business, the downgrades had a limited effect on our business. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">71 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>DISCLAIMER </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Local
currencies and constant currency exchange rates </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This report contains certain information about our results and financial condition in USD for the
Americas and GBP for the United Kingdom because those businesses operate and are managed primarily in those currencies. Certain comparative information presented on a constant currency basis eliminates the effects of changes in currency exchange
rates. None of this information is a substitute for or superior to financial information about us presented in EUR, which is the currency of our primary financial statements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT

statements as defined in the US Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. The following are words that identify such forward-looking statements: believe, estimate, target, intend, may, expect, anticipate, predict, project, counting on, plan,
continue, want, forecast, should, would, is confident, will, and similar expressions as they relate to our company. These statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to
predict. We undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. Readers are cautioned not to place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements, which merely reflect company expectations at the time of writing.
Actual results may differ materially from expectations conveyed in forward-looking statements due to changes caused by various risks and uncertainties. Such risks and uncertainties include but are not limited to the following: </FONT></P> <P
